skill.name: esm
skill.description: Comprehensive toolkit for protein language models including ESM3 (generative multimodal protein design across sequence, structure, and function) and ESM C (efficient protein embeddings and representations). Use this skill when working with protein sequences, structures, or function prediction; designing novel proteins; generating protein embeddings; performing inverse folding; or conducting protein engineering tasks. Supports both local model usage and cloud-based Forge API for scalable inference.

content.user_title: Generate and analyze proteins with ESM models
content.value_statement: Design novel proteins and extract biological insights using state-of-the-art protein language models. Transform protein sequences into embeddings for downstream analysis or generate new sequences with specific structural and functional properties.
actual_capabilities: Generate novel protein sequences using ESM3 multimodal modeling across sequence, structure, and function
Predict protein structures from sequences and perform inverse folding to design sequences from structures
Extract high-quality embeddings from protein sequences using ESM C models for downstream ML tasks
Apply function annotations to guide protein generation toward specific biological properties
Process protein batches efficiently using Forge API for scalable cloud inference
limitations: Local models require GPU resources for acceptable performance
Forge API requires registration and API token for cloud-based inference
Generated proteins require experimental validation before practical use

use_cases.title: Design novel proteins
use_cases.description: Generate new protein sequences with desired structural and functional properties for drug discovery or enzyme engineering.

use_cases.title: Extract protein embeddings
use_cases.description: Convert protein sequences into numerical embeddings for classification, clustering, or similarity analysis.

use_cases.title: Predict protein structures
use_cases.description: Predict 3D structures from amino acid sequences or design sequences that fold into target structures.

prompt_templates.title: Generate protein sequence
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a novel green fluorescent protein with 238 amino acids using ESM3. The chromophore region should be at positions 65-75. Use function conditioning to guide the generation.

prompt_templates.title: Inverse fold structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Load the structure from target_protein.pdb and use inverse folding to generate a sequence that folds into this structure. Set temperature to 0.7 for diversity.

prompt_templates.title: Extract embeddings
prompt_templates.prompt: Load ESMC-600m model and generate embeddings for these protein sequences: [sequence1, sequence2, sequence3]. Return the embedding vectors for downstream analysis.

prompt_templates.title: Chain-of-thought design
prompt_templates.prompt: Use chain-of-thought generation to design a thermostable enzyme. First generate structure, then refine sequence based on structure predictions, and finally predict function annotations.

output_examples.input: Generate a novel antimicrobial peptide with 30 amino acids using ESM3

best_practices: Start with smaller open models like esm3-sm-open-v1 for prototyping before scaling to production models
Use temperature parameter to control diversity - lower values for deterministic results, higher for exploration
Validate generated sequences through structure prediction or experimental testing before practical applications
anti_patterns: Using generated proteins without any validation - always verify sequences through structure prediction
Ignoring function annotations when they are relevant to your protein design goals
Processing very large batches locally without GPU resources - use Forge API for scalability

faq.question: What is the difference between ESM3 and ESM C?
faq.answer: ESM3 is a generative model for creating new protein sequences. ESM C is an encoder-only model optimized for extracting embeddings from existing sequences.

faq.question: Do I need a GPU to use ESM?
faq.answer: ESM models run on GPU for speed. CPU is possible but very slow. Cloud Forge API handles computation remotely without local GPU requirements.

faq.question: How do I get a Forge API token?
faq.answer: Register at https://forge.evolutionaryscale.ai to obtain your API token for cloud-based inference with larger ESM3 models.

faq.question: What are masked positions in protein generation?
faq.answer: Use underscore '_' to mask positions. The model generates amino acids for masked positions while preserving unmasked sequence regions.

faq.question: How many steps should I use for generation?
faq.answer: Start with num_steps equal to the number of masked positions. More steps increase quality but take longer. Experiment to find the right balance.

faq.question: Are generated proteins ready for lab use?
faq.answer: No. Generated proteins are computational predictions. Experimental validation in a wet lab is required before any practical application.
